key_points: Alec Baldwin discussed his choice of weapon with Rust armorer Hannah Gutierrez-Reed via email before the fatal shooting on the 'Rust' movie set.
Baldwin requested a larger gun for the rehearsal, according to an affidavit from Detective Alexandria Hancock.
A search warrant was issued to acquire Baldwin's cell phone for a forensic download to acquire all contacts, text messages, social media accounts, data, and GPS data from the device.
The search warrant was sought after Baldwin's cooperation in providing the phone was contingent on a warrant being issued.
Baldwin's civil attorney, Aaron Dyer, stated that Baldwin is cooperating with authorities and emphasized the need to protect personal information on Baldwin's phone.
Baldwin insisted in an ABC News interview that he did not pull the trigger; he claimed the gun fired when he released the hammer.
Lisa Torraco, attorney for Rust assistant director Dave Halls, supported Baldwin's claim that he did not pull the trigger.
The incident resulted in the death of 42-year-old cinematographer Halyna Hutchins and injuries to director Joel Souza.
The detective believes Baldwin's phone may contain evidence of the commission of a crime.
Discussions about the choice of gun and accessories for the production were conducted through email between Baldwin and Gutierrez-Reed.
spokespersons: Aaron Dyer (Civil attorney for Alec Baldwin)
Lisa Torraco (Attorney for Rust assistant director Dave Halls)
